sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
2D Materials have attracted widespread attention due to their extraordinary physical and chemical properties. These materials possess strong in-plane chemical bonds between their constituent atoms and weak interaction between the layers. Several elemental as well as compound 2D materials have been reported. The area of elemental 2D materials came into fore after the discovery of graphene which is an atomically thin monolayer of covalently bonded sp2 hybridized carbons. Graphene has emerged as a sensational material due to high electric and thermal conductivity, high surface area and extraordinary mechanical properties.[1–3] But graphene has a strong drawback for fabrication of transistors due to its zero bandgap. Through surface functionalization or doping, it is possible to change the properties of graphene. For example, graphene oxide (GO) shows insulating properties.[4] Nitrogen and boron doped graphene show band opening and concomitantly field emission properties.[5–7] Doped graphene finds applications in batteries,[8] supercapacitors,[9] and water splitting.[10,11] The enormous success of graphene has ignited intense interest for inorganic graphene analogues. Some of the elements that are located around carbon in the periodic table have been experimentally realized as such analogues (Figure 1). Atomically thin sheets of group-III and post-carbon group-IV elements including B (borophene), Si (silicene), Ge (germanene) and Sn (stanene) have been synthesized on various substrates, but they have not been isolated as freestanding sheets due to the absence of their layered allotropes in Nature. It has been theoretically proposed that they are promising 2D topological insulators and high temperature superconductors.[12–15]
Inspired by graphene, researchers have explored existing semiconducting layered crystals that could be peeled down to freestanding single monolayer flakes. A decade after exfoliation of graphite to graphene, Liu et al. exfoliated black phosphorus (layered allotrope of phosphorus) down to single monolayer sheet called phosphorene.[16] Phosphorene may replace graphene and transition metal dichalcogenides in the future electronic devices. The most remarkable properties of phosphorene are thickness tuneable direct bandgap, high carrier mobility, high in-plane anisotropy and mechanical flexibility.
Phosphorene may also find application in transistors,[16,17] batteries,[18] supercapacitors,[19] and water splitting.[20,21] The application of phosphorene is thwarted by its poor stability under ambient conditions which has been improved to some extent by chemical functionalization.[20,22] Phosphorene led to the discovery of other group-V elemental materials including arsenene,[23] antimonene,[24,25] and bismuthene,[26] which are 2D monolayers of arsenic (As), antimony (Sb), and bismuth (Bi) respectively. Arsenene and antimonene are predicted as indirect bandgap semiconductors with a larger bandgap compared to that of phosphorene, while bismuthene is semimetallic with a very small bandgap.[27] Due to strong spin-orbit coupling, bismuthene is a 2D topological insulator.[26]
Figure 2 shows the structural models of the experimentally known 2D graphene analogues of group-III, IV and V. All these post-graphene layered materials have a corrugated, puckered or buckled structure. Some of these materials have also been realized as graphene-like flat sheets by epitaxial growth. Experimental investigation of many of these elemental 2D materials is still in their infancy, but the available theoretical and the experimental reports are encouraging. In this review, we present the recent progress on the synthesis, structure, properties and applications of these elemental 2D materials.

sections.heading: 2.1.1. Borophene
sections.text:
Boron forms a large number of allotropes through complex B B bonds. As many as 16 allotropes of boron are known to date of which α-rhombohedral, β-rhombohedral, γ-orthorhombic and γ-tetragonal are thermodynamically stable.[28,29] These 3D allotropes comprise of the icosahedral B12 units as the building blocks. Structures of the small allotropes of size upto B36 (for example, B7, B12 , B13 +, B19
and B36) prefer to form planar or quasi-planar structures.[30–33] Notable among them is B36 which is a bowl-shaped cluster with periodic hexagonal holes in triangular lattice.[33] The hexagonal holes can be viewed as the building unit of extended graphene-like boron nanosheets. The B36 cluster can also be constructed from the smallest boron cluster B7 which exhibits a quasi-planar structure with one B atom at the centre of each B6 hexagonal unit. B36 cluster can, therefore, be assumed as the origin for various forms of borophene. After boron deposition at a substrate temperature of 823 K, STM topography images show a homogeneous phase and a more corrugated striped phase (highlighted with red and white arrows respectively in Figure 3e). The structure of the stripped phase is a buckled triangular lattice without hexagonal holes. The homogeneous phase is metastable relative to the striped phase. At a low rate of boron deposition, stripped phase nanoribbons were obtained (highlighted with a blue arrow in Figure 3e). These monolayer borophene structures are metallic with highly anisotropic electronic properties as suggested by scanning tunneling spectroscopic (STS) measurements. Through a similar strategy, Feng et al. obtained two perfectly ordered S1 and S2 phases of borophene on the Ag(111) substrate (Figure 3f, g).[39] The structures of S1 and S2 phases correspond to β12-borophene (η =1/6) and χ3-borophene (η =1/5) respectively which are composed of the trigonal lattice with hexagonal holes in different directions (η is the hexagonal hole density; the ratio of the number of hexagonal holes to the number of boron atoms in the parent triangular lattice).[40] The growth of borophene sheets depends on the substrate temperature and a small difference in the temperatures can cause structural differences because the formation energies of β12borophene and χ3-borophene are close. At a temperature <500 K, disordered fragments of boron clusters are obtained, while monolayer of S1 phase is formed at ~570 K. At 650 K, a transition of the S1 phase to the S2 phase occurred with coexistence of both the phases in 650–800 K range. At higher temperatures, the S1 phase completely transforms to the S2 phase. Alternatively, the S2 phase can directly be synthesized on Ag(111) substrate at a temperature of ~680 K. The nanosheets are stabilized through chargetransfer interaction with the substrates. Borophene with hexagonal hole density of η =1/12 has been obtained on Au(111) surface. During synthesis boron diffuses deep into the Au substrate at high temperatures and segregates to the surface to form borophene sheets upon cooling the substrate.[43]
With the deficiency of one valence electron than carbon, boron shows fairly similar properties to carbon, such as a short covalent radius and flexibility to adopt sp2 hybridization, favoring formation of 2D boron allotropes. Because of the

One can visualize the borophenes as the honeycomb lattices with boron adatoms to compensate for the electron deficiency. sections.heading: 2.2. Group IV Elements
sections.text:
The interatomic bond lengths in the post-carbon group-IV 2D materials (i. e., silicene, germnene and stanene) are significantly longer which prevent them from forming strong π-bonds, unlike in the case of graphene.[15] They form buckled sheets with mixed sp2-sp3 hybridization which enables strong overlap between the π-bonding pz orbitals. The buckling increase from 0.0 Å (graphene) to 0.85 Å (stanene) on moving down the group which influences their physical and chemical properties.[15] Due to strong spin-orbit coupling (SOC), the buckled graphene analogues show 2D topological insulator properties. These materials are predicted to be zero-gap semiconductors if SOC is not taken into account and electric field not applied. The calculated spin-orbit bandgaps at Dirac points are 1.5–2.0 meV, 23.9–30.0 meV and 0.1 eV for silicene, germanene and stanene respectively which are larger compared to that of graphene (<0.05 meV).[15]

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Silicene
sections.text:
Silicene is a buckled sheet of silicon, first predicted by Takeda in 1994.[53] Other groups predicted 2D silicene to be stable with a low buckling of 0.044 nm. Some other properties of silicene are similar to those of graphene such as gapless semi-metallicity and massless Dirac fermions.[54,55] Due to strong SOC and tuneable bandgap under an electric field, the properties of silicene deviate from those of graphene. Silicene can host topologically non-trivial electronic states,[56–59] spin-polarized edge states,[60,61] and a gate-tunable bandgap,[62] which allow silicene-based devices to conserve quantum information and support spin-based computer logic. Most of the theoretical work was unnoticed until silicene nanoribbons were synthesized on an Ag substrate by Aufray et al. in 2010.[63] Silicene has been synthesized not only on Ag,[64–68] but also on several other substrates such as ZrB2,
[69,70] and Ir.[71] Ag(111) is reported to be the more suitable substrate due to its weak chemical interaction with Si which prohibits alloy formation. Voit et al. synthesized a 4×4 phase of silicene on a Ag(111) substrate by Si molecular beam epitaxy and characterized it by STM, STS and angleresolved photoemission spectroscopy (ARPES).[68] Subsequent studies have found co-existence of multiple phases of silicene on a Ag(111) substrate, including some metastable phases.[65]
Under external electric field and interface interactions, bandgap of silicene can be opened which makes it useful for optoelectronic devices. Tao et al. have proposed silicene encapsulated delamination with native electrodes (SENDE) method to fabricate a silicene field effect transistor (FET) operating at room temperature.[72] Figure 4 shows the schematic of various steps involved in this process. Initially, epitaxial
silicene is synthesized on Ag(111) thin film deposited on mica substrate followed by in-situ Al2O3 capping. Encapsulated delamination yields silicene sandwiched between Ag(111) and Al2O3. Subsequently Ag film serves as contact electrode. This work demonstrates a Dirac-like ambipolar charge transport in silicene devices with a carrier mobility of ~100 cm2V 1 s 1.
In contrast to conventional epitaxial methods, soft chemical routes are currently receiving attention due to their low cost and mild reaction conditions. A typical example is the topochemical deintercalated of layered Zintl calcium disilicide (CaSi2) into layered polysilane (Si6H6) and siloxene (SiH3(OH)3) in aqueous HCl. CaSi2 contains pre-formed silicene-like sheets separated by planar monolayers of Ca2+.[73] The layered polysilane or siloxene structures are formed by a backbone of puckered Si 2D layers similar to silicene with weak interaction between the sheets. Mechanochemical lithiation can exfoliate these sheets which can be functionalized with organic ligands.[74–79]

Bulk germanane is a layered material with a significant van der Waals gap of 5.9 Å between the layers. It can easily be exfoliated down to a mono-layer germanane.[94–96] Germanane exhibits a buckled structure with a mixed sp2-sp3 hybridization of Ge atoms. The protons bind directly with the pz orbitals of Ge layer, leading to a direct bandgap opening at the Γ-point. sections.heading: 2.2.3. Stanene (tinene)
sections.text:
Buckled monolayer stanene is a non-trivial system as predicted by various theoretical calculations.[105–107] In the early 1990s, thin films of tin (α-Sn) were epitaxially grown on various substrates, many of which could have contained 2D stanene-like sheets, but no information about their structures was provided.[108,109] In 2015, Zhu et al. fabricated buckled monolayer stanene by MBE on a metallic Bi2Te3(111) substrate.
[110] The thickness and growth of the nanosheets were monitored by reflected high-energy electron diffraction (RHEED) and STS. The nanosheets were not smooth due to in-plane compressive stress or hydrogen adsorption. ARPES measurements indicated two hole pockets at the Γ-point which are characteristics of stanene caused by breaking of the inversion symmetry on the substrate. The calculated band structure agreed well with ARPES measurements along the Γ-M direction but not along the Γ-K direction.[110] In other words, signatures of a topological state were not observed, which may be due to the saturation of pz orbitals of Sn by the adsorbents (such as hydrogen). The topological state is determined by pz orbitals which are sensitive to the environment. Zang et al. have found that pz orbitals of stanene are automatically passivated during synthesis which leads to the absence of the topological states in buckled stanene.[111] In stanene grown on an insulating PbTe(111) substrate, the pz orbitals of the bottom sublattice are passivated by the substrate itself and those of the upper sublattice are passivated by hydrogen.[111] Strain-engineered stanene films grown on many substrates such as Sb(111),[112] and Ag(111),[113]
do not show the predicted non-trivial states. Maniraj et al. synthesized stanene on Au(111) surface in UHV chamber with base pressure <1×10 10mbar, showing linearly dispersing
band at the Γ-point with an exceptionally high Fermi velocity of 1×106 m/s.[114]
Some calculations predict that stanene with low buckling is more stable than the highly buckled one.[115,116] Deng et al. have grown high-quality graphene-like ultraflat stanene by lowtemperature MBE on Cu(111) substrate (Figure 6).[13] The ultraflat stanene sheets are stabilized by the lattice stretching and strong substrate interactions. ARPES measurements show an inplane s p band inversion along with a SOC induced topological gap of ~0.3 eV. This work stimulates future research on using more ultraflat graphene-like materials for topology-related applications. Liao et al. have discovered superconductivity in few-layer stanene grown on a PbTe/Bi2Te3/Si substrate, while bulk α-Sn is a semi-metal.[117] The superconducting transition temperature (Tc) effectively enhances on changing the thickness of PbTe buffer layer. This effect emerges at NPbTe=6, and the Tc doubles when NPbTe exceeds this thickness (N=number of layer of PbSe). A transition from a single-band to a two-band superconductor has been realized on doubling of Tc. sections.heading: 2.3.1. Phosphorene
sections.text:
Phosphorene is synthesized by exfoliation of black phosphorus (BP) which is the most stable allotrope of phosphorus at room temperature (the other allotropes of phosphorus include white, red and violet phosphorus).[16,17] Extensive theoretical and experimental investigations have proved that phosphorene exhibits a thickness tuneable direct band-gap in the ~0.3 eV (bulk) to ~2.0 eV (monolayer) range, carrier mobility of 1,000 cm2V 1 s 1 and an on/off ratio of 105.[16,17,118] Due to these unique properties, phosphorene bridges the prolonged energy gap between layered semimetal (e. g., graphene) and semiconducting transition-metal dichalcogenides (e.g., MoS2 and MoSe2).
[118–122] In addition, phosphorene is a potential anode material for batteries.[123–127] The history of phosphorene dates back to 1914 when Bridgman synthesized its bulk counterpart, black phosphorus (BP) from white phosphorus.[128] The X-ray structure shows that BP crystallizes in the orthorhombic system.[129,130] Under high pressure, a phase transformation of BP has been observed from orthorhombic to rhombohedral or simple cubic phase. BP crystals can be synthesized from other allotropes such as red phosphorus by varying the pressure ð< 10 3 mbarÞ and temperature (823–973 K).[131–133]

sections.heading: 2.3.1.1. Structure and Synthesis
sections.text:
α-Phosphorene, the isolated single layer of BP, is a puckered 2D structure of P6 rings with a chair form (henceforth α-phosphorene will be called phosphorene). Each phosphorus atom is bonded to three neighbouring phosphorus atoms by covalent P P bonds with two different bond lengths of 2.224 Å (l1) and 2.244 Å (l2) and bond angles of 96.34° (θ1) and 103.09° (θ2) (Figure 7a, b). The l1 bond connects the in-plane P atoms while l2 connects out-of-plane P atoms of the puckered sheet. Due to different bond lengths and bond angles, phosphorene exhibits
strong in-plane anisotropy. The x-axis is named as the AM (armchair) direction, while the y-axis as the ZZ (zigzag) direction. Many properties of phosphorene differ significantly along these two directions. Theoretically, it has been calculated that the inplane lattice constants (a and b) are slightly expanded in fewlayer phosphorene compared to the bulk (a=4.47 Å for bulk and 4.58 Å for monolayer; b=3.34 Å for bulk and 3.32 Å for monolayer).[134] Due to the increase in the bond angle (θ2), the AM direction is much softer which leads to a more significant lattice expansion is this direction.
The synthesis of phosphorene has been carried out by several methods. The most common method is the exfoliation of BP. Mono-layer phosphorene was first synthesized by stickytape exfoliation of BP on a SiO2-coated silicon wafer.
[16] Typically, a BP crystal is placed between two pieces of scotch tape and repeatedly exfoliated until few-layer to mono-layer thin flakes are obtained on the tape. The exfoliated flakes are then transferred onto SiO2-coated silicon substrate for characterization and device fabrication. Monolayer phosphorene has been characterized by AFM and Raman spectroscopy. The step height of ~0.85 nm obtained in AFM image confirms the presence of single-layer phosphorene (Figure 7c). The Raman spectrum of single layer phosphorene showed the characteristic A1g, B2g and A 2 g modes which are blueshifted compared to the bulk (Figure 7d). Generally, on thinning, these bands show blueshift as well as a decrease in the band intensities.[135–137] A direct bandgap of 1.45 eV has been obtained for the monolayerphosphorene by photoluminescence (PL) measurements.[16]
Although mechanical exfoliation produces high-quality phosphorene, but it contaminates the sheets with the adhesive. This can be avoided by using poly-dimethylsiloxane (PDMS) instead of scotch tape.[138] Phosphorene from PDMS can easily be transferred onto other substrates of interest. By using a combination of mechanical exfoliation and Ar+ plasma treatment, high-quality 1–5 layer phosphorene has been produced.[136] The thickness of the plasma-treated phosphorene has been measured by optical contrast spectra as well as AFM (Figure 7f–h).
Because of the low yields, mechanical exfoliation does not meet large scale requirement of phosphorene for the practical application.[139,140] Solvent exfoliation gives large-scale phosphorene from bulk BP. In this method, the BP crystal is sonicated in suitable solvents to form a stable colloidal solution of mono to few-layer phosphorene. This process typically includes three steps: (1) immersion of BP crystal in the solvent, (2) sonication, and (3) separation of exfoliated BP sheets from non-exfoliated bulk by centrifugation. To avoid degradation, the solvent must be anhydrous and de-aerated. Brent et al.

Raman scattering. Out of the six Raman active modes (A1g, A 2 g B1g B2g B 1 3g and B 2 3g) of phosphorene, three modes (A 1 g, B2g and A2g) are detected when the incident laser is perpendicular to the sample plane.[163] The Raman spectrum of phosphorene is affected by thickness as well as in-plane anisotropy. Angleresolved polarized Raman spectroscopy (ARPRS) has revealed that the intensities of A1g, B2g and A 2 g bands along AM and ZZ directions depend on the polarization angle of the incident and scattered laser as well as on the sample orientation.[142,164] In monolayer phosphorene, the highest and lowest intensities of the A2g mode are obtained when linearly polarized excitation laser is aligned parallel (θ=0°/180°) and perpendicular (θ=90°) respectively to the AM direction.[164] Intensities of the A1g and B2g modes remain unchanged.[164] Another study has found that the B2g mode disappears under parallel alignment (α=0°/180°) of the polarization vectors of the incident and scattered laser, while A1g and A 2 g modes are forbidden in cross-polarization configuration (α=90°).[165] When the sample is rotated in-plane anticlockwise by 45°, all the three modes are detected at α=0°/ 180°, while the B2g mode disappears when α approaches 90° and the other modes become much weaker.
Uniaxial strain causes significant changes in the position of the Raman bands of phosphorene.[166–168] Under ZZ strain, both B2g and A 2 g (out-of-plane) modes show monotonic redshifts when the material is stretched and blueshifts when compressed (Figure 9a).[166] The energy gap between A1g and B2g modes
decreases when stretched but increases when compressed, while the A1g (in-plane) mode remains almost unaffected. The B2g mode is sensitive to the ZZ strain, indicating that the atomic displacement is mainly along the ZZ direction. In contrast, all three Raman modes show monotonic shifts under AM strain (Figure 9b). The B2g and A 2 g modes show redshifts under compression and blueshifts under stretching while the A1g mode shows a blueshift under compression and a redshift on stretching. Also, the magnitude of frequency shifts is more under the ZZ strain than that under the AM strain.
Changes in the Raman spectrum of phosphorene due to electrons and holes doping has been examined experimentally and theoretically. The modes with Ag symmetry (A 1 g and A 2 g modes) soften significantly on electron doping, while they remain unaffected by hole doping.[169] The modes with Bg symmetry are insensitive to both electron and hole doping. Rao and co-workers have found that the Raman modes of phosphorene are sensitive to molecular charge transfer induced electron and hole doping. All the three Raman modes show softening as well as broadening on both electron and hole doping, with the hole doping causing more marked effects (Figure 9c–h). Tetrathiafulvalene (TTF), tetracyanoethylene (TCNE) as well as many other organic molecules have been employed for molecular charge-transfer studies.[170] Raman scattering of phosphorene is affected by temperature.[171,172] Under ambient conditions, the intensity ratio of A1g/A 2 g bands decreases significantly due to oxidation.[20,143]

S is the Seebeck coefficient at the temperature difference of T.[184] The Seebeck coefficient of bulk BP is 335�10 μV/K at room temperature.[185] Its ZT value is 0.72 at 800 K which can be increased upto 0.87 by strain.[186]
These values are comparable with many other thermoelectric materials but significantly less than those of the best thermoelectric materials such as layered Bi2Te3, Sb2Te3, and SnSe with ZT>2.0 at room temperature.[187] For BP films>15 nm thickness, thermal conductivities along the AM and ZZ directions are ~20 and ~40 Wm 1K 1 respectively (anisotropic ratio= ~2) which decreases for thinner films.[188] For phosphorene, the thermal and electric transport are aligned orthogonal to each other which gives rise enhanced thermoelectric effect. The predicted maximum ZT is 0.2–0.7 in doped phosphorene at a low temperature which increases upto 2.5 at 500 K.[187,189]
Mechanical properties. Phosphorene exhibits attractive mechanical flexibility and negative Poisson’s ratio.[190–192] Firstprinciples calculations by Wei et al. have suggested that monolayer phosphorene has good mechanical flexibility while sustaining a tensile strain up to 27% and 30% along ZZ and AM directions respectively.[193] The strain causes flattening of the sheet in the AM direction, rather than stretching the P P bonds in this direction. The maximum and minimum values of the Young’s modulus of 166 and 44 GPa have been found along the ZZ and AM directions respectively.[193] The Young’s modulus for all other directions are in the 44–166 GPa range, with the average value of 94 GPa. The anisotropy in Young’s modulus originates from the puckering of the sheet in the AM direction which unfolds under tension and folds under compression. In other words, BP sheets are softer in the AM direction, due to the fact that bond angles are changed easily with little effect on bond lengths. Few-layer BP showed a Young’s modulus of 58.6�11.7 in ZZ and 27.2�4.1 GPa in the AM direction as measured by nanoindentation in AFM.[194] Wang et al. have found that Young’s modulus decreases monotonically with increasing thickness of BP nanosheets with the maximum value of 276�32.4 GPa for BP with thickness of 14.3 nm.[195] It remains unchanged at 89.7�26.4 GPa for the thickness >30 nm. Clearly, the Young’s modulus of phosphorene is much less than graphene (1,000 GPa,[196]) and MoS2 (250�100 GPa,
[197]) making it an excellent material for flexible devices.
Chemical reactivity and functionalization. Although phosphorene is thermodynamically stable, but it degrades into phosphoric acid and other oxide species under ambient conditions by reacting with oxygen and water. Atomically thin sheets degrade faster which is a major challenge for its applications.[198–203] By making use of lone-pair electrons on P atoms, phosphorene can be chemically functionalized with suitable reagents to protect its surface against oxidation. It has been functionalized by forming covalent, coordination as well as van der Waals interactions. Ryder et al. have functionalized mechanically exfoliated ~10 nm thick BP nanosheets with 4- nitrobenzene-diazonium (4-NBD) and 4-methoxybenzenediazonium (4-MBD) (Figure 11).[22] Formation of P C bonds between phosphorus and phenyl ring facilitates the functionalization as shown by XPS, Raman spectroscopy, AFM as well as by DFT

Druenen et al. have observed reduced FET performance at a higher degree of functionalization with 4-NBD and 4-MBD due to mixed covalent and non-covalently functionalization.[204] To circumvent this problem, they reacted BP with relatively less reactive diaryliodonium salts and proposed the reaction mechanism. This strategy provides functionalization of both P and O sites with aryl groups.
The diazonium chemistry of phosphorene is extended to covalently attach fluorescent dye Nile Blue 690 (NB-690) to BP sheets.[205] NB-690 is first converted to corresponding diazonium salt and then reacted with BP nanosheets. Dye modified BP shows ambient stability as well as a strong fluorescence band at ~680 nm. Because of the non-toxicity, NB-690 functionalized BP can be used in photothermal cancer therapy. Other strategies such as non-covalent functionalization,[223–225] and doping have also been employed.[226]
It is worth mentioning that the buckled form of phosphorene (also called β-phosphorene or blue phosphorene) has been theoretically predicted which does not have naturally occurring bulk counterpart.[227] It has recently been realized on Au(111) substrate by MBE under ultrahigh-vacuum conditions.[228–231] The electronic bandgap of single layer blue phosphorene on Au (111) measured by STS is 1.1 eV.[230]

sections.heading: 2.3.2. Arsenene
sections.text:
Arsenene, a single buckled honeycomb 2D layer of arsenic, has emerged as an attractive material in the last few years. An indirect bandgap of 2.49 eV and a high charge carrier mobility have been predicted for arsenene.[232] A small biaxial strain can cause indirect to direct bandgap change-over in mono-layer arsenene.[232] There have been several theoretical studies on arsenene, but only a few experimental studies are reported. Rao and co-workers have synthesized freestanding few-layer arsenene (6-12 layers) nanosheets by probe sonication of gray arsenic in NMP under an inert atmosphere (Figure 13a, b).[23] The fewlayer arsenene is separated by ultracentrifugation and characterized by TEM, Raman spectroscopy and XPS. The TEM and AFM images show thin layer nature of arsenene (Figure 13c–e). The Raman spectrum of few-layer arsenene shows in-plane Eg and out-of-plane A1g bands at 197.2 and 256.5 cm
1 respectively which are blueshifted compared to the bulk arsenic (Figure 13f). A bandgap of ~2.38 eV is measured from the absorption spectrum which agrees with the calculated value. Further by changing solvent from polar (NMP) to a non-polar (toluene), arsenene nanodots are obtained which show blue emission in the 400–460 nm range. Arsenene nanosheets have been covalently functionalized with 4-NBD which show enhanced ambient stability.[23] Tsai et al. have prepared ~14 nm thick arsenene nanoribbons on an InN/InAs substrate by plasmaassisted synthesis (Figure 13g).[233] In this process, plasma treated N2 ions react with InAs to form InN. During this process, As atoms squeeze out of the surface to form multilayer arsenene nanoribbons after annealing. sections.heading: 2.3.3. Antimonene
sections.text:
Antimonene is a buckled honeycomb monolayer of covalently bonded Sb atoms. Theoretically, it has been predicted that monolayer antimonene exhibits an indirect bandgap of 2.28 eV, high carrier mobility, good electric and thermal conductivity.[27,232,235] Synthesis of atomically thin Sb films dates back to several decades, mainly emphasizing epitaxial growth of Sb metal on semiconducting substrates such as GaAs (110),[236,237] Bi(111),[238] and Si(111).[239] Properties of these Sb films were poorly understood due to the strong interaction of Sb with the substrates. Recently, several groups have prepared high-quality monolayer antimonene on PdTe2, [240] Ge(111),[241] and Ag(111) substrates,[242,243] by MBE. The low-energy electron diffraction (LEED) and STM measurements show that the thickness of the monolayer β-antimonene grown on PdTe2 is 2.8 Å.[240] Fortin-Deschênes et al. have grown mono and fewlayer antimonene nanosheets on Ge(111)-c(2×8) substrate by Sb4 deposition at room temperature, followed by annealing at 300 °C.[241] A step height of 2.66 Å indicates the deposition of monolayer antimonene on Ge(111). A weak interaction between antimonene and the substrate is suggested by LEED measurements. Scanning tunnelling spectroscopy (STS) and DFT calculations suggest that single and few-layer antimonene on Ge substrate to be semimetallic. A continuous and single-crystal antimonene film has been epitaxially deposited on MoS2/ sapphire substrate at a low temperature of 200 °C. Antimonene sheets show a selective growth atop MoS2 due to different interface energies of antimonene between MoS2 and sapphire.[235] β-Antimonene is formed by partial sp3 hybridization between in-plane sp2 and out-of-plane pz orbitals. If the in-plane sp2 orbitals do not hybridize with the out-of-plane pz orbital, the buckled honeycomb can become graphene-like flat honeycomb which has been synthesized by Shao et al. on an Ag(111) substrate.[242] The formation of flat antimonene monolyer is confirmed by LEED, STS and first-principles calculations. The thickness of the flat antimonene is 2.20 Å.[242] Properties of flat antimonene have not been investigated experimentally but it is believed that it widens the scope of atomically-thin 2D materials. Unlike MBE which requires a close lattice matching, van der Waals (vdW) epitaxy provides an opportunity to synthesize materials with a large lattice mismatch. Lu et al. carried out a cathodic exfoliation of Sb crystals with a Pt wire of 0.5 mm diameter as the counter electrode (anode).[248] The Na+ ions released from Na2SO4 electrolyte intercalate the Sb crystals and facilitates exfoliation. Nanosheets of ~31.6 nm thickness with a lateral dimension of ~10.3 μm were obtained. The Eg and A1g Raman modes have been observed at 113.8 and 150.9 cm 1

A significant charge transfer of 0.62 je j per TCNQ molecule is observed with TCNQ which is about twice as large as that observed for phosphorene (0.35 je j).[255] A charge-transfer bandgap of ~1.05 eV in the functionalized antimonene have been predicted. The functionalization protects the antimonene sheets against the formation of Sb2O3 due to ambient oxidation. Layered antimonene oxide is predicted to be a direct bandgap semiconductor, covering a wide range of bandgaps from 0 to 2.28 eV depending on oxygen contents.[256]

sections.heading: 2.3.4. Bismuthene
sections.text:
Bismuthene, the single layer of bismuth, is a buckled honeycomb structure similar to the β-phase of As and Sb. The small bandgap of 30–40 meV (for bulk) and 0.3–0.5 eV (for monolayer), high atomic weight and concomitantly strong SOC make 2D bismuth a topological insulators. [15,257,258] The early synthesis of atomically thin 2D bismuth are carried out by MBE. Nagao et al. synthesized such film of ~1.0 μm edge length on Si surface and characterized it by STM and RHEED.[259,260] The metallic nature is examined by conductance measurements. Walker et al. have grown single-crystalline thin films of β-Bi on Si-substrate with a thickness of 6–50 nm and demonstrated the dry transfer of the films from the host substrate by using epoxy with a double cantilever beam fracture technique.[261] The films maintain their characteristic properties and crystalline nature post-transfer. Reis et al. have synthesized single-layer bismuthene on an insulating SiC(0001) substrate.[26] The SiC substrate is prepared by dry-etching of commercial n-doped Si-terminated 4H-SiC(0001) under an H2 atmosphere. It is remarkable that the bismuthene exhibits flat graphene-like structure due to the strain effect of SiC (Figure 16a, b). The lattice constant is considerably larger than that of the buckled bismuthene reported earlier on a SiC substrate.[262] A topological energy gap of ~0.8 eV and conductive edge states are observed in the flat bismuthene (Figure 16c).
Freestanding few-layer bismuthene has been prepared by liquid as well as acid-intercalated exfoliation of bulk Bi crystals.[263–265] The few-layer bismuthene nanosheets have been characterized by TEM and Raman spectroscopy (Figure 16d–f). The liquid exfoliated bismuthene exhibits nonlinear characteristics with a nonlinear refractive index of ~10 6 cm2/W.[264] Wetchemical methods can also be used for the synthesis of ultrathin bismuthene nanosheets through reduction of bismuth nitrate under reflux condition.[266] Han et al. have prepared ultrathin Bi nanosheets by the in situ topotactic transformations of bismuth oxyiodide (BiOI) nanosheets which in turn prepared by reducing bismuth nitrate under solvothermal conditions.[267]
The topotactically prepared Bi nanosheets electrochemically reduce CO2 into formate with impressive Faradaic efficiency, high selectivity, large current density and good conversion efficiency for electricity-to-formate.

sections.text:
FET is a switching device used in modern electronics. BP FETs comprised of BP sheet connected to three electrodes, source (S), drain (D) and gate (G) have been fabricated. The gate-tosource electric field (VGS) created by the gate voltage can amplify (on-state) or switch off (off-state) the current flow from the source to the drain. sections.heading: 3.2. Photocatalytic Hydrogen Evolution Reaction
sections.text:
Photocatalytic water splitting produces hydrogen and oxygen in the presence of a semiconductor which can absorb photon. This reaction is an uphill process with a significant change in Gibbs free energy (ΔG) of +273.2 kJmol 1 or 1.23 eV. Semiconductors with the CBM at a more negative potential than the reduction potential (H+/H2: 0.0 eV vs. NHE at pH 0) and the VBM at a more positive potential than the oxidation potential (O2/ H2O: +1.23 eV vs. NHE at pH 0) of water can catalyse overall water splitting reaction. With the bandgap of 0.3–2.0 eV, phosphorene can absorb light in the visible to infrared region. Calculations suggest that at 25 °C and pH 0, phosphorene is suitable for the reduction half-reaction (i. e., 2H+!H2).
[21] The water redox potential changes with pH and at a high pH of 8.0, the VBM and CBM of phosphorene become suitable for the water splitting reaction.[296] Catalysts based on bare BP nanostructures produce trace amounts of hydrogen. Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) activities of phosphorene composites with other catalytically active materials (such as CdS, ZnS, gC3N4 and AuNP) are significantly higher compared to bare phosphorene. Stable functionalized phosphorenes have shown superior HER activity, which arises from the enhanced ambient stability as well as water dispersibility. The efficient sensitization by eosin Y (EY) further increases the HER activity. Electron transfer from EY to phosphorene drives the photocatalytic proton reduction on phosphorene nanosheets.[20] The last few years have seen several phosphorene based photocatalysts. Table 4 provides a comparison of the HER activity of phosphorene based photocatalysts.

sections.heading: 3.3. Energy Storage, Batteries and Supercapacitors
sections.text:
Energy storage devices such as rechargeable batteries and supercapacitors have been attracting much research attention in recent years. In most of the commercial Li ions batteries (LIBs), graphite is used as the anode material which has a low specific capacity of 372 mAhg 1.[1,297] Chemically modified graphene materials such as rGO exhibits improvements in lithium-storage capacity.[6] Various new materials with higher capacity have been examined as reliable alternatives. Group-V layered materials including black phosphorus, arsenic, antimony, and bismuth have attracted attention as a possible replacement for graphite. These materials are endowed with high theoretical specific capacities for lithium and sodium ions (Table 5) which is attributed to their unique layered structure
and high Li/Na uptake capacity.[298,299] Figure 18a shows the schematic illustration of sodiation/desodiation process in bulk BP. The large volume expansion upon charging/discharging process, however, leads to poor capacity retention. Composites of BP as well as other group-V layered elements with conducting carbon-based fillers including porous carbon, carbon black, graphite and graphene show superior capacity performance which can be tuned with the carbon contents.
Anodes of bulk BP modified with carbon black show capacity enhancement from 67 mAhg 1 to 1,814 mAhg 1 with 90% efficiency for the first cycle.[300] Sun et al. have found that a BP-graphite composite prepared by mechanochemical reaction shows high initial discharge capacity of 2,786 mAhg 1 as well as an excellent lifetime upto 100 cycles with 80% capacity retention (Figure 18b, c).[301] A hybrid vdW heterostructure of few-layer phosphorene (<10 nm) with graphene shows a specific capacity of 2,440 mAhg 1 (calculated based on the mass of BP only) with 83% capacity retention after 100 cycles (Figure 18d–f).[18] The graphene layers serve as the elastic buffer to accommodate the volumetric expansion of phosphorene during the formation of Na3P with a negligible (~40 mAhg
1) contribution to the capacity.[18] These studies have proved that BP/graphite or BP/graphene composites are good anode materials for next-generation high energy batteries, but the retention capability is still not good enough for commercial applications. Further studies are required to explore and verify the extraordinary battery properties of black phosphorus.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion and Outlook
sections.text: In this review, we have presented the structures, synthesis, properties and applications of post-graphene elemental 2D nanomaterials. The 2D nanomaterials formed by group-IV and V are of considerable interest due to their attractive electronic and optical properties. The properties of phosphorene have been explored for possible applications in field effect transistors (FETs), water splitting, energy storage as well as sensors, making phosphorene a valuable material in the post-graphene era. Some of the other inorganic graphene analogues such as silicene, germanene, arsenene and antimonene may find potential applications as well. Materials such as silicene and stanene are stable only under vacuum and there is a need to stabilize them under normal conditions.
